text: Altered DNA - binding specificity mutants of <extra_id_0> EKLF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> Sp1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> show that <extra_id_0> EKLF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is an activator of the <extra_id_0> beta-globin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> locus control region in vivo .

text: The locus control region of the <extra_id_0> beta-globin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> cluster contains five DNase I hypersensitive sites ( 5'HS1-5 ) required for locus activation .

text: 5'HS3 contains six G-rich motifs that are essential for its activity .

Members of a protein family , characterized by three zinc fingers highly homologous to those found in transcription factor <extra_id_0> Sp1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , interact with these motifs .
Because point mutagenesis can not distinguish between family members , it is not known which protein activates 5'HS3 .

We show that the function of such closely related proteins can be distinguished in vivo by matching point mutations in 5'HS3 with amino acid changes in the zinc fingers of <extra_id_0> Sp1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> EKLF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
Testing their activity in transgenic mice shows that <extra_id_0> EKLF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is a direct activator of 5'HS3 .
